    - [x] [Make sure you've added a new test if existing tests do not effectively test the code changed](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#before-submitting)

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @sethvs Please add tests and a description that new formats we get.

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body: As mentioned in the issue, this **is** a potential breaking change, so the committee must review.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @PowerShell/powershell-committee reviewed this and the benefit doesn't justify the breaking change as the PR is currently defined so we cannot accept this as-is.  @sethvs if you want to pursue this, you would need to consider other needs of Here Strings which may require a new token so that this doesn't break existing scripts.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
To add a couple other points: 

* this doesn't buy you much from a readability perspective when you can't indent the lines between the opening and closing operators, e.g.:

```powershell
function foo {
        $a = @"
Some text
that can't
be indented.
        "@
}
```

* it may be a reasonable user expectation that if they had a trailing amount of whitespace, that it'd be included in the here-string, e.g.

```powershell
function foo {
        $a = @"
Some text
that can't
be indented.
        "@ # why wouldn't the whitespace on this line be included?
}
```

* given that we don't get additional indentation in the content of the here-string, "good enough" readability is achievable with this syntax:

```powershell
function foo {
        $a = 
# inline python code cares about whitespace
@"
if 1 == 1:
    print("yes")
else:
    print("no")
"@
}
```

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body: My original design years ago (prototyped but never shipped) would strip as much indentation on each line as we found before the terminator - this made here strings quite readable indented, but it is potentially confusing.

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body: @lzybkr That's kind of how I would expect any such change to behave. That said, I'm not sure it is worth it at this point.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
@sethvs Thanks for your contribution! 

I close the PR based on PowerShell Committee conclusion. We should continue the discussion in related Issue.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
@lzybkr we discussed that option (to use the terminator as indicator of stripping leading whitespace), but the main discussion was it would be confusing to the end user.  Perhaps a new token would resolve that.  Personally, I would like to do something like this:

```powershell
  $content = @"
    This is
    my text.
    "@
```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
We could use quotes in last line to set size of the desired indentation:
```c#
$content = @"
        This is
        my text.
""""""""@
```

title: Allow indentation of here-string closing characters.
